Concatenate â„_{tâˆ’1} and x_t and then perform a linear transformation
This operation is called Concatenation
It is also represented by a semicolon ;
         â„_t = tanh(W_h (â„_{tâˆ’1} ; x_t))

content after edit:
As mentioned earlier, this is the basic structure of the RNN model and the corresponding formula. When the output vector o_t passes through the tanh function to produce the final h_t, this formula essentially (pointing to the figure below) concatenates the two vectors, x_t and h_(t-1), which are inputs to this RNN model, into a single vector and then transforms that vector through a typical fully connected layer.

For example, assume that h_(t-1) is a 3-dimensional vector. Then, the output vector of this linear combination, here denoted as o_t, after passing through tanh, becomes the hidden state vector h_t at the current time step. This vector must also be 3-dimensional, like h_(t-1), so that this vector can serve as h_(t-1) input for the next time step in the same function.

So, the matrix W_hh here means it plays the role of transforming h_(t-1) into h_t. This matrix will be a square matrix of size 3x3.

Next, x_t is also transformed through a linear transformation represented by W_xh. W_xh thus means the transformation from x_t to h_t.

The resulting vector after this transformation must have the same dimension (3) to be added to the left vector. For example, if x_t is a 4-dimensional vector, then W_xh should be a 3 by 4 matrix.

The left side of the equation concatenates the hidden state vector and the current time step input vector into one long vector. This concatenation operation is called concatenation or simply concat and is sometimes denoted by a semicolon in mathematical notation.

Then, the concatenated vector is multiplied by a single matrix formed by horizontally stacking the two matrices (W_hh and W_xh), achieving the same result as the separate linear transformations.

To understand this, consider the multiplication between the matrix and the concatenated vector: the first row vector of the matrix is dot-multiplied with the column vector to produce the first element of the output vector, and the same applies for the second row vector.

Hence, the dot product of these long vectors is equivalent to the sum of the dot products of the respective parts: the row vector of W_hh with h_(t-1), and the row vector of W_xh with x_t. This also applies to the other row vectors.

Therefore, through this relationship, we can consider (the equation below) as a fully connected layer that takes a concatenated vector of two vectors as input. Since a fully connected layer means every input node connects to every output node, the weights connecting h_(t-1) to the output layer correspond to W_hh, and those connecting x_t to the output layer correspond to W_xh.

Finally, the output vector passes through tanh to create the final hidden state vector at the current time step, which constitutes the operation of the RNN model.

content after edit:
As mentioned earlier, this is the basic structure of the RNN model and the corresponding formula. When the output vector o_t passes through the tanh function to produce the final h_t, this formula essentially (pointing to the figure below) concatenates the two vectors, x_t and h_(t-1), which are inputs to this RNN model, into a single vector and then transforms that vector through a typical fully connected layer.

For example, assume that h_(t-1) is a 3-dimensional vector. Then, the output vector of this linear combination, here denoted as o_t, after passing through tanh, becomes the hidden state vector h_t at the current time step. This vector must also be 3-dimensional, like h_(t-1), so that this vector can serve as h_(t-1) input for the next time step in the same function.

So, the matrix W_hh here means it plays the role of transforming h_(t-1) into h_t. This matrix will be a square matrix of size 3x3.

Next, x_t is also transformed through a linear transformation represented by W_xh. W_xh thus means the transformation from x_t to h_t.

The resulting vector after this transformation must have the same dimension (3) to be added to the left vector. For example, if x_t is a 4-dimensional vector, then W_xh should be a 3 by 4 matrix.

The left side of the equation concatenates the hidden state vector and the current time step input vector into one long vector. This concatenation operation is called concatenation or simply concat and is sometimes denoted by a semicolon in mathematical notation.

Then, the concatenated vector is multiplied by a single matrix formed by horizontally stacking the two matrices (W_hh and W_xh), achieving the same result as the separate linear transformations.

To understand this, consider the multiplication between the matrix and the concatenated vector: the first row vector of the matrix is dot-multiplied with the column vector to produce the first element of the output vector, and the same applies for the second row vector.

Hence, the dot product of these long vectors is equivalent to the sum of the dot products of the respective parts: the row vector of W_hh with h_(t-1), and the row vector of W_xh with x_t. This also applies to the other row vectors.

Therefore, through this relationship, we can consider (the equation below) as a fully connected layer that takes a concatenated vector of two vectors as input. Since a fully connected layer means every input node connects to every output node, the weights connecting h_(t-1) to the output layer correspond to W_hh, and those connecting x_t to the output layer correspond to W_xh.

Finally, the output vector passes through tanh to create the final hidden state vector at the current time step, which constitutes the operation of the RNN model.
